material.mattext: Which of the following could be the 95% confidence interval for p, based on the same data?
Both the third and fourth intervals could be the 95% interval for p.

Incorrect. Note that, since the p-value of the test was .001, Ho was rejected (at the .05 significance level, or even lower levels). This means that the 95% confidence interval for p cannot include .605 as a plausible value.

Incorrect. Note that, since the p-value of the test was .001, Ho was rejected (at the .05 significance level, or even lower levels). This means that the 95% confidence interval for p cannot include .605 as a plausible value.

Incorrect. Note that, since the p-value of the test was .001, Ho was rejected (at the .05 significance level, or even lower levels). This means that the 95% confidence interval for p cannot include .605 as a plausible value. While it true that, therefore, this could be a confidence interval for p (since it does not include .605), it is not the only one...

Incorrect. Note that, since the p-value of the test was .001, Ho was rejected (at the .05 significance level, or even lower levels). This means that the 95% confidence interval for p cannot include .605 as a plausible value. While it true that, therefore, this could be a confidence interval for p (since it does not include .605), it is not the only one...

Good Job! Indeed, since the p-value of the test was .001, Ho was rejected (at the .05 significance level, or even lower levels). This means that the 95% confidence interval for p cannot include .605 as a plausible value, which both the third and fourth confidence intervals satisfy. Comment: The third confidence interval is the actual one that was found in the follow up study.
